title: Menus
description: Menus display a list of choices on a temporary surface.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Menus appear when users interact with a button, action, or other control.

They can be opened from a variety of elements, most commonly icon buttons, buttons, and text fields.

contentChunks.footer: Menu
contentChunks.altText: List of options in a menu

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)Available
M2 guideline â€“ MenusAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterIn progress
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Menus should be easy to open, close, and interact with
  • Menu content should be suited to user needs
  • Menu items should be easy to scan
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color
  • Types: Dropdown menu and exposed dropdown menu are now both referred to as menu, since they differ only in the element which opens the menu surface

contentChunks.footer: Menus feature new color mappings

Color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

Configurations

Menus appear when users interact with a button, action, or other control. A few examples:

  1. Button
  2. Text field
  3. Icon button
  4. Selected text

contentChunks.footer: Menus can be opened from a number of inputs.

contentChunks.footer: Menu
contentChunks.altText: 3 example cards with headlines and body text

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Use a menu to display a list of choices on a temporary surface, such as a set of overflow actions in a top app bar.Â 

Menus allow users to make a selection from multiple options. Theyâ€™re less prominent and take up less space than a set of radio buttons or choice chips.

A menu opens upon interaction with an element (such as an icon, button, or input field) or when users perform a specific action.

contentChunks.footer: Menus display a list of choices on a temporary surface.
contentChunks.altText: List of 4 options in a menu

contentChunks.htmlValue: Menus appear in front of all other permanent UI elements.

contentChunks.footer: Menus appear in front of all other permanent UI elements.
contentChunks.altText: Menu appearing from FAB on top of UI

contentChunks.htmlValue: Menus are positioned relative to the edge of the screen or browser. They typically appear below, next to (or in front of) the element that generates them. If they are in a position to be cut off by the browser or screenâ€™s edge, the menu can instead appear to the left, right, or above the element that generates it.

contentChunks.footer: Menus can change their position to avoid being truncated by the screen or browserâ€™s edge.
contentChunks.altText: UI showing a parent dropdown menu with a cascading menu to its right

contentChunks.htmlValue: A menuâ€™s height should be at least one row less than the appâ€™s UI.

contentChunks.footer: The space between the bottom of the menu and the bottom of the screen is the same size as the height of a menu item.
contentChunks.altText: UI showing 48 dp for each menu row and another 48 dp padding between menu and bottom of screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
2. List item (including label text and optional leading icon, trailing icon, and keyboard command)
3. Divider (optional)
contentChunks.altText: Menu displaying a list of text and icon items

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

Menu containers hold all menu items.

Â 

List items

Menus display lists of options. List items can include label text, leading icons, trailing icons, and keyboard commands.

List items have interaction states including hover, focus, and press.

Display list items as disabled when they can only be used sometimes, under certain conditions. They should be displayed as disabled rather than removed.

contentChunks.footer: The Redo action is disabled when that action isnâ€™t available, and the Cut and Copy actions are disabled until content is selected.
contentChunks.altText: Menu shows 3 items that are disabled, the text color of disabled items are lighter than the active items

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Divider

Dividers can be used to separate list items into groups.

contentChunks.footer: Separate list items into groups using dividers.
contentChunks.altText: Dropdown menu displaying a list of text and icon items with 1 divider

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive layout
Bottom sheets are an alternative to menus on mobile devices. They have more space to display additional items and longer labels.

contentChunks.footer: The bottom sheet can replace an inline menu on smaller screens.
contentChunks.altText: Menu of actions (in a list) inside a modal bottom sheet

contentChunks.htmlValue: On larger screens, bottom sheets can become menus in order to preserve the intent and context of the primary content.

contentChunks.footer: On larger screens, a menu can be more appropriate.
contentChunks.altText: An adapted bottom sheet becomes a context menu

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Appearing

A menu appears when a user taps either an interactive element (such as an icon, button, or action) or content (such as selected items or text).

A menuâ€™s position on screen affects where and how it will appear. If opened at the top of the screen, it will expand downwards (to avoid being cropped).

Menus use a fade transition pattern to enter and exit the screen. The animation creates a relationship between the menu and the interactive element that generates the menu.

contentChunks.footer: Menus at different positions on screen open in different ways, adapting to the space available.
contentChunks.altText: Menu appears at top of UI and expands downward

contentChunks.footer: A menu can be triggered by an icon tap, appearing below the overflow menu icon.
contentChunks.altText: Menu appears below overflow menu icon

contentChunks.footer: A menu can be triggered by a tap-and-hold, appearing next to selected text.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of a menu appearing on tap-and-hold, after selecting text

contentChunks.footer: A menu can be triggered by selecting an input field in a document, appearing directly beneath that input field.
contentChunks.altText: Menu displays current selection

contentChunks.footer: A menu can be triggered by selecting a filter chip, appearing directly beneath that chip.
contentChunks.altText: Menu displays the currently selected item above the menu

contentChunks.htmlValue: By default, menus open with an entrance animation. However, on desktop, menus can skip the animation and open instantly instead.

contentChunks.footer: Desktop menus have the option to open instantly.
contentChunks.altText: Menu displays the currently selected item

contentChunks.htmlValue:
When a menu expands, the following transitions occur:

  • A menu list fades in and has a slight downward motion
  • Stroke width of the separation line thickens, and its color changes to blue from grey
  • The text label scales down in size and moves upwards
  • A downward arrow fades out, and an upward arrow fades in


When an item on the menu list is selected, the following transitions occur:

  • Ripple appears on touch
  • Selected Text fades into the input field
  • Menu list fades out
  • Upward arrow fades out, and downward arrow fades in

contentChunks.footer: Menu with filter showing a list of states filtered by the letter C.
contentChunks.altText: Menu transitioning list with filter

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Filtering

A menu with filtering is also known as autocomplete or a combobox. As the user begins typing, menu options filter based on what's entered. This can help users quickly find the right option from a large list.Â 

Menus with filtering apply dynamic easing to the movement of suggestions as the menu changes height.

contentChunks.footer: Menu with filter showing a list of states filtered by the letter C.
contentChunks.altText: Menu transitioning list with filter

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Scrolling

If not all menu items are displayed at once, menus can be scrollable. In this state, menus show a persistent scrollbar.

contentChunks.footer: When content is scrollable, menus display scrollbars.
contentChunks.altText: Menu displays the currently selected font above the menu

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Selection

When a menu is opened from a button or icon button, the button or icon button should visually remain the same.

When a menu is opened from a text input field, the selected menu item can be displayed in that field. In some cases, the field can accept and display user input (whether or not itâ€™s listed as a menu choice).

contentChunks.footer: Tapping the icon triggers a menu. Choosing a menu option doesnâ€™t change the icon generating the menu.
contentChunks.altText: Menu appearing after icon press

contentChunks.footer: Selection in a menu opened from an input field.
contentChunks.altText: 2 menu states in the filled style, activated, with menu exposed and a selection activated, inactive and populated, with the menu displaying the selected item

contentChunks.htmlValue: Use cases

Users should be able toÂ 

  • Navigate to, open, and close a menu with assistive technology
  • Navigate between and select menu items with assistive technology
Interaction & style

Initial focus state behavior should align with platform conventions:

  • Android: no focus explicitly set
  • iOS and the web: first menu item or menu title

For exiting focus, consider platform conventions that users expect to use when exiting a menu, such as:

  • Selecting an option
  • Tapping outside of dialog
  • Using system back button

Where focus is placed after closing the menu depends on the app.

contentChunks.footer: Keyboard navigation on Android
Keyboard navigation on iOS and the web

contentChunks.htmlValue: Keyboard navigation

KeysActions
TabFocus lands on menu
Space / EnterFor closed menus: Opens menu or submenu
For open menus: Selects list itemÂ 
Up / Down ArrowsFor closed menus: Opens menuÂ 
For open menus: Moves focus to the next item
Left / Right ArrowsOpens or closes a submenuÂ 
LettersFocus moves to the next list item starting with letter
EscapeCloses menu
Note: Keyboard conventions differ slightly per platform. For example, Space / Enter opens a menu on Android while only Space opens menus on iOS.
Interactability

Disabled menu items can receive focus but aren't selectable.

A divider cannot receive focus.

contentChunks.footer: Disabled menu items can receive focus
Dividers cannot receive focus

contentChunks.htmlValue: Labeling

Accessibility labels are used with assistive technology devices like screen readers.Â 

The accessibility label should align with each list itemâ€™s text label.Â
For list items with text and icon, the accessibility label should be marked as decorative to avoid redundant verbalizations.
